title: Hereditary Neuropathy / Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease (CMT)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of hereditary motor and sensory neuropathies (Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and related disorders) in adults. Covers CMT1 (demyelinating), CMT2 (axonal), CMTX (X-linked), CMT4 (autosomal recessive), HNPP, and Dejerine-Sottas disease. Includes genetic testing strategy, electrodiagnostic classification, neurotoxic medication avoidance, supportive management, and surgical considerations. Excludes hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN) as primary diagnosis but includes in differential. Excludes pediatric-onset evaluation (but most CMT presents in childhood/adolescence with adult follow-up).

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude diabetic neuropathy as comorbid or alternative diagnosis

Genetic Testing (Stepwise Approach).rationale: First-line test: PMP22 duplication = CMT1A (~60% of CMT1); PMP22 deletion = HNPP; order if demyelinating NCS pattern (median motor NCV <38 m/s)
Second-line if PMP22 negative; CMTX1 is second most common CMT; order especially if intermediate NCV (25-40 m/s) or X-linked pattern
CMT1B; order if PMP22 and GJB1 negative with demyelinating pattern; late-onset axonal phenotype also possible
CMT2A; most common axonal CMT subtype; order if axonal NCS pattern (median motor NCV >38 m/s)
Comprehensive panel (>80 genes) if targeted testing negative; includes CMT1, CMT2, CMT4, CMTX, dHMN genes; higher yield than sequential single-gene testing in atypical cases
Consider if multigene panel negative in strong hereditary phenotype; may identify novel mutations

Extended Labs (Exclude Acquired Mimics).rationale: Exclude paraproteinemic neuropathy (anti-MAG IgM neuropathy mimics CMT1)
Anti-MAG neuropathy causes uniform demyelination mimicking CMT1; treatable
Exclude CIDP (elevated CSF protein); IgM gammopathy evaluation
Refsum disease (G60.1): elevated phytanic acid, demyelinating neuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, ichthyosis; treatable with dietary restriction
Adrenomyeloneuropathy (adult AMN): axonal neuropathy with myelopathy; X-linked

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CMT has normal or mildly elevated protein; CIDP typically >45 mg/dL; Dejerine-Sottas may have markedly elevated protein
Rule out inflammatory process; normal in CMT
Normal in CMT; low in infectious/inflammatory meningitis
Absent in CMT; present in inflammatory conditions (MS, CIDP variant)

Core Imaging.rationale: CMTX1: transient white matter lesions during metabolic stress; CMT4 subtypes with CNS involvement; exclude structural causes
Core Imaging.target: Normal in most CMT; CMTX1 may show reversible white matter changes

Core Imaging.rationale: Exclude compressive myelopathy/radiculopathy as contributing factor; hypertrophic nerves in Dejerine-Sottas
Core Imaging.target: No cord compression; may show nerve root hypertrophy in demyelinating CMT

Advanced Imaging.rationale: Assess nerve hypertrophy pattern; differentiate from CIDP or neoplastic infiltration; research use in CMT
Advanced Imaging.target: Uniform nerve enlargement (CMT1); CIDP tends to be patchy/multifocal

Advanced Imaging.rationale: Non-invasive assessment of nerve cross-sectional area; diffusely enlarged nerves in CMT1A; focal enlargement suggests acquired neuropathy or HNPP
Screen for diaphragmatic elevation (phrenic nerve involvement in CMT2C/TRPV4); scoliosis assessment; ED/ICU if respiratory distress

Pulmonary Function Assessment.rationale: Assess respiratory muscle weakness; FVC <80% predicted or >10% drop supine indicates diaphragm weakness; relevant in severe CMT, CMT2C, CMT4; ED/ICU if respiratory distress
Screen for cardiomyopathy in LMNA-related CMT2; arrhythmias in selected subtypes; ICU if cardiac concerns
Screen for conduction abnormalities; LMNA mutations associated with cardiac conduction disease; baseline before starting TCAs
Pulmonary Function Assessment.target: Normal sinus rhythm; no conduction block

Patient Instructions.item: Carry neurotoxic medication alert card or wear medical alert bracelet listing CMT diagnosis and vincristine contraindication
Return to ED if sudden severe weakness, difficulty breathing, or rapid symptom progression (may indicate superimposed GBS/CIDP)
Inform all healthcare providers (including dentists, surgeons, anesthesiologists) of CMT diagnosis before any procedure
Inspect feet daily for blisters, cuts, or pressure sores; wear well-fitting protective footwear at all times
Use AFOs and assistive devices as prescribed; do not discontinue without PT/physician guidance
Exercise regularly at moderate intensity (walking, swimming, cycling); avoid high-resistance eccentric exercise and overexertion
Do not stop gabapentin or pregabalin abruptly — taper under medical guidance to avoid withdrawal
Report new or worsening numbness, weakness, pain, breathing difficulty, or balance problems promptly
Neuropathic pain medications take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect; report side effects before discontinuing
Genetic counseling is recommended before family planning; inheritance pattern depends on CMT subtype
Contact CMT Foundation (cmtausa.org) for educational materials, support groups, and clinical trial information

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Neurotoxic medication avoidance is the single most important actionable step — document prominently in chart and allergy list
Moderate aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, cycling) improves fitness and quality of life without worsening neuropathy
Weight management — excess weight increases functional burden on weakened muscles and accelerates deformity
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, install handrails, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices as needed
Energy conservation and pacing strategies for CMT-related fatigue; plan activities with rest periods
Avoid prolonged pressure on nerves (especially HNPP): do not cross legs, use padded armrests, reposition frequently during sleep and prolonged procedures
Annual comprehensive foot and orthotic reassessment; early intervention prevents progressive deformity
Alcohol moderation (alcohol is directly neurotoxic and worsens peripheral neuropathy)

differential.features: Acquired; progressive or relapsing; proximal AND distal weakness; elevated CSF protein (>45 mg/dL); nerve ultrasound shows patchy enlargement; responds to IVIg/steroids
differential.tests: NCS (non-uniform slowing, temporal dispersion in CIDP vs uniform slowing in CMT1); CSF protein; treatment response

differential.features: Acquired; distal predominant; IgM paraprotein with anti-MAG antibodies; slowly progressive; tremor common; uniform demyelination mimics CMT1
Prominent sensory loss including pain insensitivity; autonomic dysfunction; painless injuries and ulceration; less motor involvement
differential.tests: Clinical phenotype (sensory predominant); genetic testing (SPTLC1, WNK1, IKBKAP, NTRK1)

differential.features: Distal weakness mimicking CMT; normal or mildly abnormal NCS; myopathic EMG pattern; elevated CK
differential.tests: EMG (myopathic MUPs); CK; muscle biopsy; genetic testing (dysferlin, GNE, myotilin)

differential.features: Proximal > distal weakness; fasciculations; no sensory loss; childhood onset typical
differential.tests: SMN1 deletion testing; EMG (anterior horn cell pattern)

differential.features: Ataxia, areflexia, sensory neuropathy, cardiomyopathy, scoliosis; progressive ataxia is dominant feature
Axonal neuropathy with progressive myelopathy (spastic paraparesis); X-linked; adrenal insufficiency
Demyelinating neuropathy with retinitis pigmentosa, cerebellar ataxia, ichthyosis, elevated CSF protein
Progressive axonal sensorimotor and autonomic neuropathy; cardiomyopathy; family history; late onset
differential.tests: TTR gene sequencing; tissue biopsy with Congo red stain

differential.diagnosis: Multifocal acquired demyelinating sensory and motor neuropathy (MADSAM/Lewis-Sumner)
differential.features: Asymmetric, multifocal; sensory AND motor involvement; conduction block; responds to IVIg/steroids
differential.tests: NCS (asymmetric, multifocal conduction block); treatment response
